attributes.label: customized/personalized learning
attributes.description: customized learning is based on two main concepts: first, that everyone learns at a different pace and second, that everyone learns in different ways. personalized learning is an educational approach that aims to customize learning for each student's strengths, needs, skills and interests. each student gets a learning plan that's based on what he knows and how he learns best.

attributes.label: generation global
attributes.description: The young people who are part of the Generation Global know Global challenges cannot be solved with national thinking. They use the Net to find solutions and tackle global problems at their local roots. The Global Generation brings about an economic and social shift that makes sense and social added value the central assessment criteria.

attributes.label: single-society
attributes.description: more and more people decide to be independent and free as singles. people live in partnerships, but do not strive for traditional marriages.

attributes.label: edutainment
attributes.description: the importance of lifelong learning and that it can be fun to learn is demonstrated by the great popularity of edutainment formats. the combination of learning (education) and entertainment (entertainment) covers a wide range of cultural and leisure activities. edutainment ranges from science broadcasts and interactive exhibitions to theme parks and events such as science slams.

attributes.label: co-living
attributes.description: people's biographies have developed into multi-graphics. this is reflected not least in the way people live: co-living is no longer just a model for students. shared flats for the elderly and working people as well as multi-generational houses are also becoming more popular. new communities, communities and neighbourhood networks are emerging everywhere - a development that could only come about through individualisation.

attributes.label: universal design
attributes.description: universal design concepts ensure that everyday products through to home furnishings are designed to be flexible, easy and intuitive to use with high fault tolerance. accessibility and aesthetics are no longer a contradiction. it is about simple, intuitive usability and thus fault-tolerant use of products.

attributes.label: knowledge culture
attributes.description: The megatrend knowledge culture continues unabated. Especially the interaction with the megatrend connectivity changes our knowledge about the world and the way we handle information. Enormous amounts of knowledge are generated in decentralized structures, and new forms of innovation and joint research are emerging. Knowledge is losing its elitist character and is increasingly becoming a common good; the global level of education is higher today than ever before. More complex, unpredictable demands on the labour market and new, collaborative forms of knowledge acquisition are also shifting the focus: towards lifelong learning, teaching methods - and soft skills.

attributes.label: post-demographics
attributes.description: classic sociology-demgraphic characteristics such as gender, income, place of residence, occupation or especially age are loosing significance in describing social groups.

attributes.label: startup culture
attributes.description: the army of freelancers, founders and young entrepreneurs who, with not quite straightforward cvs, give up their lives as employees in favour of a start-up is not only becoming an economic factor. with their interdisciplinarity, their business ideas, their way of working and approaching problems, they are setting an example in terms of work culture and putting established companies and entire industries under pressure to innovate.

attributes.label: day-to-day work outsourcing
attributes.description:
complexity and shortage of time in people's day-to-day life. 
more and more everyday tasks are being outsources to services and service providers.

attributes.label: corporate health
attributes.description: health management in companies goes far beyond accident prevention, company doctors and ergonomic workplaces. stress, overwork, burnout, physical and psychological complaints: to ensure performance at work, health care is no longer an individual matter. it becomes a strategic management task.

attributes.label: collaboration
attributes.description: collaboration is the often technically mediated cooperation in teams. the objective is often the generation of new ideas or problem solutions. often the collaboration is intensive, creative and limited in time. through exchange, synnovations, new connections or perspectives are created. digital communication is a strong driver.

attributes.label: free ager
attributes.description: the lifestyle of the free ager is most widespread in the age group 50plus. free ager want to focus on the things in life that are relevant for them. values such as serenity, harmony, humanity, a healthy environment and social interaction are close to their hearts. the most important thing for them is to be satisfied with themselves and to always live in the here and now.

attributes.label: betterment
attributes.description: betterment is a term to describe the process of self actualization and improvement. the importance of betterment increases because people tend to prefer self-education and self-paced learning.

attributes.label: mindfulness
attributes.description: mindfulness is the most important counter-trend to the permanent stimulus satiation of the digital age and the culture of arousal created by the media. more and more often we question the way we deal with ourselves and our real digital environment. mindfulness is more than a lifestyle issue, it is the art of not losing sight of the here and now, of knowing one's own needs and living values.

attributes.label: rural city
attributes.description: the lust for the countryside of many city dwellers, their longing for natural, tranquil, stress-free living spaces, is promoting the trend towards small-scale, village-like structures within cities. urban developers, but above all the citizens themselves, are creating hybrid places that find their expression, for example, in urban gardening, in communally used green spaces and neighbourhood initiatives. local communities thus create islands of common identity and rural idyll in their city.

attributes.label: global migration
attributes.description: in a globalised world, many countries have continuous flows of immigrants and emigrants. especially for societies with an ageing population, low birth rates and simultaneously high labour demand, immigration is an enormous opportunity. the challenge lies in shaping cultural diversity in a creative and constructive way.

attributes.label: digital health
attributes.description: digital technologies are playing an increasingly important role in health care and individual health behaviour. in the case of critical vital signs, for example, physicians can provide feedback without the patient having to see a doctor. digital health enables better interaction between patients, doctors and service providers.

attributes.label: golden mentor
attributes.description: golden mentors want to remain active for a lifetime and share their experiences with others. representatives of this lifestyle are generally between 55 and 79 years old and are often already retired - or "unretired". many of them are still working and are actively involved in the economy and society.

attributes.label: bio-boom
attributes.description: the consumption of organic products - food, but also clothing, furniture and cosmetics - continues to grow unabated. a large number of organic seals, certificates and guidelines are used to ensure the credibility of organic products. in addition to ecological motives, for most consumers "organic" also stands for higher quality and thus not least for more enjoyment.

attributes.label: platform economics
attributes.description: a platform economy is a form of economy in which online platforms form the basis for the exchange of resources and the mediation of business relationships. they control the provision of goods and services and thus access to the market. the best-known examples include companies such as airbnb or uber, which do not own any real estate or vehicles themselves, but are increasingly becoming market-determining global players.

attributes.label: talentismus
attributes.description: the "war for talents", the competition for skilled workers, is intensifying worldwide. in the knowledge society, clever, creative minds are increasingly in demand. however, it is no longer just a question of standardised qualifications and comparable degrees. instead, diverse talents are in demand. they are becoming an important economic and social currency for companies, but also for each individual. global competition demands constant development of personnel management and employer branding, but also of individual employability.

attributes.label: condensed spaces
attributes.description: condensed spaces are inner-city urban spaces with high population, building, infrastructure and mobility density. most people, most living space and most traffic are to be found in a very small area. the quality of life of the entire city and even the region depends on the successful design and organisation of the condensed spaces.

attributes.label: Neo-Biedermeier
attributes.description: The lifestyle of the Neo-Biedermeier is largely an alternative to the progressive lifestyles of modern nomads and urban Matchas - but for this very reason it has a decisive influence on the markets for living and housing. What distinguishes it is the return to the cosiness and security of the home, the idyll of the private and the traditional family as the linchpin of the lifestyle. This focus is partly fed by an escape from change: the fear of the challenges of globalization and, in particular, the increasing loss of privacy in an increasingly digitalized world. Similar to the German bourgeoisie in the 19th century, who withdrew into the apparent security of the home to escape political restrictions, social turbulence and the upheavals of industrialization - the Biedermeier era.

attributes.label: neo-tribes
attributes.description: neo-tribes are characterized by the fact that their members freely choose to belong and they are often relevant to certain phases or areas of life.

attributes.label: neo-ecology
attributes.description: Organic markets, EU plastics regulations, the energy turnaround - the megatrend neo-ecology extends into every area of our everyday lives. Whether personal purchasing decisions, social values or corporate strategy - even if not always apparent at first glance, it is increasingly becoming one of the most powerful drivers of our time, not least due to technological innovations. The megatrend is not only bringing about a realignment of the values of global society, culture and politics. It is changing the fundamental foundations of entrepreneurial thinking and action.

attributes.label: virtual/augmented reality
attributes.description: a virtual campus or e-campus, refers to the online offerings of a college or university where college work is completed either partially or wholly online, often with the assistance of the teacher, professor, or teaching assistant. many colleges and universities now offer such courses (or entire degree programs) either partially or wholly online.

attributes.label: megacity
attributes.description: megacities are cities with 10 million or more inhabitants. many of these huge metropolises have high growth rates. already today, about one in eight of the world's inhabitants lives in one of the 30 or so megacities. according to un forecasts, their number will rise to almost 50 by 2035. the sheer size of the megacities poses enormous challenges in terms of infrastructure, quality of life and sustainability.

attributes.label: silver society
attributes.description: The megatrend Silver Society is having an impact worldwide. Around the globe, the population is aging and the number of older people is increasing. At the same time, people are staying healthy longer. This creates a completely new phase in life after the usual retirement age. This phase of life is becoming longer and offers room for self-development in new lifestyles in old age. A new mindset paves the way for a society that is becoming more vital than ever before, especially due to the changed age structure. It bids farewell to the youth craze and fundamentally reinterprets age and ageing.

attributes.label: individualization
attributes.description: Individualization is the central cultural principle of the Western world and is increasingly unfolding its power to make an impact globally. The complex megatrend has reached its temporary peak in many prosperous nations and has become the basis of our social structures. The megatrend is re-coding society: it affects value systems, consumption patterns and everyday culture equally. In essence, individualization means freedom of choice. However, its effects are complex and create both apparent countertrends such as a "we" culture and new constraints. Individualization is closely interwoven with the megatrends urbanization, gender shift and connectivity.

attributes.label: infolust
attributes.description: nfolust is the strong desire for relevant information, which is insatiable and spreading from the online realm to the bricks and mortar world on its path to ubiquity.

attributes.label: recognition of cognitive diversity
attributes.description: Cognitive diversity is about including people who have diverse styles of problem solving and can offer unique perspectives because they think differently. Contrary to demographic diversity, which focuses on achieving a mixture of statistical features such as gender or age, cognitive diversity focuses on achieving a mixture of how people engage in intellectual activity, such as making associations or drawing conclusions.

attributes.label: health literacy
attributes.description: health has become a self-responsible task. more and more people are expanding their health competence - their health literacy. they obtain information on health topics from various sources and form their own opinions. this enables them to confidently face doctors at eye level.

attributes.label: courses designed by employers
attributes.description: emerging trend where companies act like a full-service training and talent development solutions provider both for their employees and exteral users, including students.

attributes.label: liquid youth
attributes.description:
According to Bauman, we are in a transition from a "solid" to a "liquid" modernity, a "liquid modernity" in which conventional orders are no longer applicable and individuals must be increasingly flexible and adaptable.

These observations coincide with the realities of the highly complex network society. Today's youth grow natively into these contingent contexts and are able to adapt to the new, liquid conditions much better than other social groups. This makes it plausible to call today's youth "liquid youth".

attributes.label: bike-boom
attributes.description: the bicycle is transforming from a recreational device to the mode of transport of choice, especially in cities. cycling is not only ecological, inexpensive and healthy, but in city centres it is now often the faster alternative to the car or public transport. cities of the future will incorporate cycle paths, bike-sharing stations and parking spaces into their infrastructures to further support the bike boom.

attributes.label: diversity
attributes.description: diversity means diversity of people, for example in terms of age, gender, origin, cultural background, qualifications etc. in view of fundamental changes in the world of work and business, employee diversity is seen as an increasingly important success factor for companies in terms of innovative ability and resilience.

attributes.label: multigraphy
attributes.description: unpredictable biographies, linear biographies are becoming multifaceted, parallel and jumping.

attributes.label: Multi Performer
attributes.description: For the Multi Performer, the profession is at the centre of his life. Anyway, he is of the opinion that nowadays leisure time and profession cannot be so clearly separated. Success in his profession is very important to him, and if someone makes an effort, he is convinced that anyone can work their way up. He sees good, versatile education as an essential condition for a successful life. He is performance-oriented, disciplined and conscientious. He enjoys his work, likes to take on responsibility and has ambitious plans and goals to get ahead in life. He is always open to new opportunities and challenges, yet he appreciates a secure job. The Multi Performer defines himself through his performance in working life and lives the values of the well-earning middle of society: individuality and self-realization are obligatory.

attributes.label: on-the-go markets
attributes.description: the increasingly mobile lifestyle also leads to growing markets on the move. purchases are made at newly growing sales outlets practically "in passing". airports, for example, already generate a large part of their sales through retail space. the retail trade is also increasingly pushing into the foreground at petrol stations, railway stations and other third places.

attributes.label: mobile-education
attributes.description: m-learning or mobile learning is learning across multiple contexts, through social and content interactions, using personal electronic devices. a form of distance education, m-learners use mobile device educational technology at their convenient time.

attributes.label: modern nomands
attributes.description: Nobody stands for an urban and at the same time global mindset like the Modern Nomad. He enjoys the diversity and informality, while at the same time playing a decisive role in shaping the dynamics of large cities. Modern nomads never stay in the same place for long and try to absorb the cultural and local characteristics of the regions in which they move. With this interest, they reinforce the development that economic sectors are emerging in cities and communities that deliver just that: authenticity, social connections and regional or local experiences.

attributes.label: progressive province
attributes.description: parallel to the progressing urbanisation, villages and rural regions are experiencing a renaissance. local visionaries, transitory architecture, openness, storytelling and self-confidence can turn entire regions into progressive provinces. they bring an urban mindset to rural areas and can revitalize entire villages.

attributes.label: connectivity
attributes.description: Connectivity is the most powerful megatrend of our time. The principle of networking dominates social change and opens a new chapter in the evolution of society. Digital communication technologies are fundamentally changing our lives, reprogramming socio-cultural codes and giving rise to new lifestyles and patterns of behaviour. In order to successfully accompany this fundamental change, companies and individuals need new network competencies and a holistic-systemic understanding of digital change.

attributes.label: omline
attributes.description: the omline trend describes a digital mindfulness, derived from a combination of "online" and the meditative primal sound "om". at its core is a holistic, real-digital mindset that enables a reflective approach to networked digitality. the aim is not to seal off from new media, but rather a reflective approach to the internet: a real-digital balance in fully networked living environments.

attributes.label: work-life blending
attributes.description: the intelligent combination of private and professional life, e.g. through home office models and mobile office solutions, will be a major task in the coming years. instead of continuing to spasmodically attempt a balancing act between two seemingly separate worlds, work-life blending stands for a new approach to reconciliation, in which employers and employees find solutions to compensate for the increasing burden of business and professional demands.

attributes.label: slow culture
attributes.description: today's work, leisure and family life often takes place under a considerable amount of time. from a certain point, high flexibility and being on the go are perceived as a burden. that is why more and more people in our hypermobile society are looking for ways to slow down, to live and consume more carefully and consciously.

attributes.label: education business
attributes.description: in the knowledge society, education becomes one of the most important goods. more and more commercial education providers are recognising this and profiting from a growing demand. parents also rely on their children's knowledge advantage or professional private tutoring outside of public education. similarly, more and more investments are being made in services provided by universities, further education offers, coaching and the field of online education.

attributes.label: good citizens
attributes.description: the good citizens take responsibility or initiate changes, they support ecological and social initiatives - whether in the neighbourhood or in global initiatives. for them, orientation towards the common good and self-realization are not contradictory. this avant-garde lifestyle embodies an adult community spirit and a forward-looking eco-pragmatism.

attributes.label: sustainable development
attributes.description: education for sustainable development empowers learners to take informed decisions and responsible actions for environmental integrity, economic viability and a just society, for present and future generations, while respecting cultural diversity.

attributes.label: mind sport
attributes.description: this is exactly what characterizes resonance sports: they trigger an impulse that changes our life and goes beyond the expected positive effects on our physical and mental well-being. the sports of the future can deepen the relationship between man and the world

attributes.label: podcasting
attributes.description: a podcast is an episodic series of digital audio files that a user can download in order to listen. many universities and companies have their own podcast channels where they not only upload educational content but also try to engage more students/employee through them.

attributes.label: fuzzynomics
attributes.description: fuzzynomisc is described as the collapse between consudmer and producer. p2p buying and selling, crowdfunding and the on-demand economy have disrupted the brand-consumer dynamic. fuelled by every individuals desire for control, authenticity, and self-expression, the move towards participatory consumption will continue to evolve. for education field, students can become the teacher and the professors can be the one who learn from them.

attributes.label: omni channeling
attributes.description: cross-channel content strategy that organization use to improve their experience and drive better relationships with their audience across point of contacts.

attributes.label: globalization
attributes.description: Trade wars, diplomatic crises, cyber-attacks, international corporate powers - globalization is all too often perceived as a problem today. However, the challenges associated with an increasingly complex and interconnected world must not obscure the positive effects of globalization. For while politicians are still attempting to regulate global processes with old nation-state mechanisms, world society has long since moved into the future of the 21st century. Many current trends, from the postal growth economy to direct trade and the rise of the Generation Global, are reinforcing the global dynamics that will continue to move the international system in a progressive direction in the coming years.

attributes.label: lifelong learning
attributes.description: working environments, job profiles, qualification requirements - all this is constantly changing. a degree once obtained is usually not enough for a lifetime. employees have to undergo continuous further training, acquire additional qualifications or even completely new skills. lifelong learning, however, is not only a professional necessity, but also the desire of many people to develop themselves in many different ways.

attributes.label: micro housing
attributes.description: micro housing means as much quality of life as possible in the smallest possible space. tiny houses often combine innovative green tech with homely design and optimal use of space. the pioneer of this trend is japan: in tokyo, each resident has an average of 19 square meters of living space at his or her disposal. but micro housing is also becoming increasingly popular in other growing cities and for modern nomads around the world.

attributes.label: coding integrated in every study program (iot, ml, ai etc.)
attributes.description: although computer programming was once seen as a skill reserved for geeks and computer nerds, its now regarded as an essential ability for 21st century learners and is becoming a key component of many curriculums, even in primary schools. but coding education can also be beneficial for students who arent necessarily interested in pursuing computer programming, but would like to gain a better understanding of technology and how its shaping our world.

attributes.label: seamless mobility
attributes.description: fluids and seamless transitions from one means of transport to another become possible thanks to digital networking. integrated concepts, which no longer think, organise and offer mobility in different means of transport, but along mobility chains, enable multimodal mobility. the use of different modes of transport will be intelligently interlinked and thus function more and more smoothly, including integrated booking and payment options.

attributes.label: multipolar world order
attributes.description: Instead of a few individual national superpowers, the world is increasingly dominated by several powerful forces. Whether military, political or economic, the trend is towards several major global powers that share influence and compete with each other, but also cooperate.

attributes.label: hygge
attributes.description: warm atmosphere where you enjoy good things in life together with nice people.

attributes.label: forever youngsters
attributes.description: for forever youngsters, reaching retirement age is by no means the beginning of retirement - but rather the start of the best phase of their lives. full of curiosity and thirst for action, they throw themselves into activities, get involved in charitable causes or realize long-cherished dreams. in all of this, people with this lifestyle also take particular care of their health.

attributes.label: digital creatives
attributes.description: The digital creative is at home in the real digital world and is significantly influenced by the megatrends connectivity and knowledge culture. 4.2 percent of Germans see themselves as part of this lifestyle, for whom it is a matter of course to not only passively use technology but to actively apply it - for them it is the central tool with which they develop their creative potential. Companies can learn for themselves from their digital competence. And: No matter what new technology comes onto the market, Digital Creative is an early adopter.

attributes.label: Neo-Hippies
attributes.description: The neo-hippie spends his time enjoying life, having fun, spontaneously doing something - always looking for the next party, for variety and entertainment. And always looking to look good doing it. However, he is not superficial, but rather attaches great importance to community: He is not interested in the hedonistic experience itself, but in the shared experience with his circle of friends, whom he also likes to invite to his home and in whom he invests a lot of time and energy.

attributes.label: resonance society
attributes.description: individualistic search movement of defense, rebellion, detachment from traditional ties and the striving for autonomy turn into question of belonging.

attributes.label: youniverse
attributes.description: this buzzword has various meanings, however, in education, it is described as the state when everything is customized so that everyone feels unique.

attributes.label: learning analytics
attributes.description: learning analytics is the measurement, collection, analysis and evaluation of data about learners and their context. the aim is to understand and optimise learning and the learning environment. access to the data becomes possible as learning offers and processes are increasingly supported by digital, virtual systems. special software makes it possible to precisely record and evaluate individual learning processes.

attributes.label: guided pathways
attributes.description: guided pathways start with the students' end goals in mind, and then rethink and redesigns programs and support services to enable students to achieve these goals. the model focuses on laying out a clear, cohesive academic program for students and aligning the support services to assist students down their program path to successful completion.

attributes.label: self-balancer
attributes.description: The Self Balancer leads a mindful lifestyle and has made it his life goal to be always balanced and with himself inside. For him, his own well-being is more important than the thought of eating healthy food at all costs or motivating himself to engage in sports. In this way he manages to set and pursue his priorities in life very clearly, without being distracted by external influences.

attributes.label: new work
attributes.description: Digitisation throws people back on their humanity - especially in working life. If machines can do certain jobs better than humans in the future, we will begin to think about the meaning of work. If work no longer needs us, what do we need work for? New Work describes an epochal upheaval that begins with the question of meaning and transforms the world of work from the ground up. The age of the creative economy has dawned - and it is time to bid farewell to the rational meritocracy. New Work focuses on the development of the potential of every single person. Because work is at the service of people: We no longer work to live, and we no longer live to work. In the future, it is all about the successful symbiosis of living and working.

attributes.label: co-working
attributes.description: The increasing mobility of employees in the creative industries in particular is creating new focal points for working together and sharing knowledge. Co-Working Spaces are community offices where, for example, self-employed people or project teams can rent temporary workplaces. Often these spaces are more than just offices - they are places of encounter, exchange and often conviviality.

attributes.label: just-in-time learning/boothcamps
attributes.description: just-in-time learning is an approach to individual or organizational learning and development that promotes need-related training be readily available exactly when and how it is needed by the learner. bootcamps are training camps for learning various types of skills ranging from technical till physical skills.

attributes.label: micromobility
attributes.description: in the increasingly dense urban traffic, the demand for efficient mobility solutions is growing. public transport is evolving towards individual mass mobility and is completed by a dense network of so-called public private vehicles and microcarriers such as electric scooters, autonomous shuttle vehicles, bicycles and other micro-mobiles. flight taxis are also being developed and already tested.

attributes.label: smart city
attributes.description: the smart city approach looks beyond isolated technological solutions to find intelligent systems that offer holistic solutions for a wide range of urban challenges and master them through meaningful networking. however, a smart city is not only technologically smart, but also socially intelligent by taking into account the knowledge and wishes of its inhabitants.

attributes.label: dash delivery
attributes.description: due to the ongoing boom in e-commerce, the fast, efficient delivery of goods is becoming a challenge. retailers and logistics providers are vying for the most innovative solutions in terms of responsiveness on the last mile to the customer. convenience and a near-real-time supply chain to shorten delivery times are becoming an important competitive advantage.

attributes.label: un-retired
attributes.description: as part of the new multigraphy of people, "un-retirement" refers to the lifestyle of older people who would actually be retired but have no interest in being passive pensioners. unretired people want to continue working or enjoy their free time to the full. as the elderly grow older and healthier, a period of time opens up that is characterised by activity, serenity and zest for life.

attributes.label: microlearning
attributes.description: microlearning is a holistic approach for skill based learning and education which deals with relatively small learning units. it involves short-term-focused strategies especially designed for skill based understanding/learning/education. microlearning refers to micro-perspectives of learning, education, training and skill development.

attributes.label: Urban Matcha
attributes.description:
The creative lifestyle of Urban Matcha is a central player in modern cities where innovations and trends are created - in the metropolises of Europe it can hardly be overlooked: It stands out for its clothing style and consumer behaviour, it makes opinions and acts as a trendsetter. He enjoys the attention he generates and uses his pioneering role to communicate his values.

"Ich will Stadt und Natur, Genuss und Gesundheit, Familie und Freiheit"

attributes.label: playfulness
attributes.description: our hyper-networked world with its high level of complexity and constant surprises requires playfulness - a playful way of thinking and acting. open-ended, explorative trial and error, trial-and-error and the understanding of failure as feedback make up the playful approach through which we learn complex things as children. this playfulness must be reactivated in all areas of adult life.

attributes.label: healing architecture
attributes.description: whereas functional aspects have long been the focus of architecture, in the future it will increasingly be a question of the emotional qualities of rooms. as a prevention against hectic, stress and unhealthy environmental influences, buildings are becoming a medicine, so to speak. innovative strategies focus on the healing effect of rooms and on materials as part of holistic concepts of modern health care.

attributes.label: social business
attributes.description: innovative strength and inventive talent are the drivers of a successful economy, which can help to solve the challenges and problems of our time faster and more efficiently than charitable or humanitarian non-profit initiatives.

attributes.label: digital literacy
attributes.description: digital literacy refers to a confident and self-assured approach to the challenges of digitality. the skills that form the basis for this are of a cognitive, social and also cultural nature: processing the digital "information overflow", strengthening human interaction in digitised contexts - and the general willingness to open up to the new requirements of digitally networked communication.

attributes.label: creative economy
attributes.description: The cultural and creative industries are now seen as an independent economic field and include the diverse media industry and the design industry as well as architecture, marketing, the arts and the rapidly growing gaming industry. With its economic performance, the creative industries have already caught up with the top sectors such as the automotive industry and mechanical engineering in many places.

attributes.label: nearshoring
attributes.description: The choice of location for companies is increasingly influenced by the goal of operating and manufacturing close to their markets. Losses in flexibility, quality problems and changes in wage levels in different parts of the world led to a reversal of the trend. Offshoring, which was favoured for a long time, is now increasingly turning into nearshoring: production takes place where the customer is.

attributes.label: digital reputation
attributes.description: the question of what reputation and esteem people enjoy is increasingly determined by their reputation in social networks and the information that can be found about them on the internet. this applies to an even greater extent to the valuation of companies and brands.

attributes.label: urban manufacturing
attributes.description: the desire for individuality and quality, a growing awareness of local value creation and the increasing demand for regional products are creating a new market for small manufacturing companies in cities. they are developing into business models beyond the niche. whether lifestyle objects, clothing, delicacies or furniture - thanks to the proximity to the customer, the city is being reclaimed as a production location.

attributes.label: flexitarian
attributes.description: "less meat, more quality of life" is the motto of part-time vegetarians. flexitarians focus less on morals and more on pragmatism. for example, they do not completely and always do without meat (vegetarians) or even all animal products (vegans). their philosophy is to find the right balance and prefer to consume less and better meat.

attributes.label: collaboration platforms
attributes.description: a collaboration platform is a category of software that adds broad social networking capabilities to work processes. the goal of a collaboration software application is to foster innovation by incorporating knowledge management into work processes so that users can share information and solve project problems more efficiently.

attributes.label: gig economy
attributes.description: the gig economy is a new form of economy in which people earn their living through situational, short-term jobs. the digital possibilities of the platform economy serve as ideal intermediaries between customers and these independent, freelance contractors. uber-drivers, delivery men, lyricists etc. move from one job to the next, just as musicians used to do from gig to gig.

attributes.label: game-based learning
attributes.description: the gamification of learning is an educational approach to motivate students to learn by using video game design and game elements in learning environments. the goal is to maximize enjoyment and engagement through capturing the interest of learners and inspiring them to continue learning. gamification, broadly defined, is the process of defining the elements which comprise games that make those games fun and motivate players to continue playing, and using those same elements in a non-game context to influence behaviour. in other words, gamification is the introduction of game elements in a non-game situation. the core concept behind game-based learning is teaching through repetition, failure and the accomplishment of goals. video games are built on this principle.

attributes.label: business ecosystems
attributes.description: the term "business ecosystem" describes the increasing networking of companies and industries - and thus also the blurring of their boundaries - under the omens of digitization. from a certain degree of networking and the associated automation, economic networks become partially or self-organized, and value chains become ecosystems.

attributes.label: online/blended learning
attributes.description: online learning is a way of distance learning which allows to get education. blended learning is an approach to education that combines online educational materials and opportunities for interaction online with traditional place-based classroom methods. it requires the physical presence of both teacher and student, with some elements of student control over time, place, path, or pace.

attributes.label: Sense careerist
attributes.description: The situation is similar with the Sinn careerist (forward-thinker), to which around 6.3 million Germans feel a part of. He strives for a meaningful relationship with his fellow human beings, a responsible relationship with the environment and a harmonious interaction between body and mind. He places questions of meaning at the centre of every consideration. In an economic world based on autonomy, it is impossible to imagine life without him: he acts out of conviction. People with this lifestyle question things for their meaning and value - and turn away if they cannot recognize it. What looks like egoism is in reality a valuable indication of things that will no longer work in a value-based economy.

attributes.label: Forward-thinker
attributes.description:
The forward-thinking person is the shaper of the future: as tomorrow's leader, he drives forward the change in society with enormous assertiveness, social competence and a playful ease. 

He seems like a classic career type, but in fact he uses his assertiveness and creative knowledge to do something for his fellow human beings and the environment. This lifestyle, to which around nine percent of the German population feels a part, is thus a prime example of the Next Growth concept.

attributes.label: mobility
attributes.description: The world in the 21st century is not only characterized by a further growing need for mobility but above all by an increasing variety of mobility forms. Individualisation, connectivity, urbanisation and neo-ecology determine tomorrow's mobility. Technical innovations and changing human needs will become the driving force behind new forms of mobility: networked, digital, post-fossil and shared. What we are experiencing is an evolution of mobility. We are at the beginning of a new, multi-mobile age.

attributes.label: open innovation
attributes.description: Open innovation processes are spreading in all industries and at companies as diverse as Samsung, General Electric and LEGO. However, it is not only individual processes that are changing, but the entire production logic: the decisive factor for competitiveness is no longer the innovations in the division of labour in production and its products within a fixed company organisation - but open and collaborative problem solutions with actual or potential customers and other players.

attributes.label: soft-skills development
attributes.description: soft skills are a combination of people skills, social skills, communication skills, character or personality traits, attitudes, career attributes, social intelligence and emotional intelligence quotients, among others, that enable people to navigate their environment, work well with others, perform well, and achieve their goals with complementing hard skills. the importance of the following soft skills is trending nowdays - problem solving, critical thinking, ethical, intercultural understanding, social and self- awareness.

attributes.label: un-residence
attributes.description: As part of the new multigraphy of people, "un-retirement" refers to the lifestyle of older people who would actually be retired but have no interest in being passive pensioners. Unretired people want to continue working or enjoy their free time to the full. As the elderly grow older and healthier, a period of time opens up that is characterised by activity, serenity and zest for life.

attributes.label: DIY
attributes.description: The trend towards do-it-yourself (DIY) and open exchange of knowledge is becoming increasingly important as a social phenomenon. DIY initiatives operate on a commons-based basis, i.e. they understand jointly developed production technologies, methods, information and knowledge as common property. Inter- and transdisciplinary cooperation, rapid information exchange and collaboration are of utmost importance.

attributes.label: self-paced learning
attributes.description: self-paced instruction is any kind of instruction that proceeds based on learner response. the content itself can be curriculum, corporate training, technical tutorials, or any other subject that does not require the immediate response of an instructor.

attributes.label: digital platforms
attributes.description: A collaboration platform is a category of software that adds broad social networking capabilities to work processes. The goal of a collaboration software application is to foster innovation by incorporating knowledge management into work processes so that users can share information and solve project problems more efficiently.

attributes.label: green tech
attributes.description: Green tech refers to technologies that attempt to avoid environmental pollution from the outset, reduce it or repair damage that has already occurred. In addition, the use of Green Tech helps companies to manage scarce and increasingly expensive raw materials more efficiently.

attributes.label: post growth economy
attributes.description: the global economy continues to grow, but much more slowly, and in some places stagnation is already evident. companies in such environments need new business models and must become less dependent on growth. this automatically raises the question of the purpose of doing business: ever more profit? - or maybe better, socially and ecologically more advantageous problem solutions for customers and other stakeholders?

attributes.label: sense economy
attributes.description: New dimensions of value creation away from thinking in terms of growth and profit maximisation are coming to the fore: social added value, sustainability, a happy workforce, social progress. Companies that want to be successful in the post-growth capitalist era must themselves live and promote these new value concepts of the economy of meaning.

attributes.label: competency-based education
attributes.description: competency-based learning is an approach to education that focuses on the students demonstration of desired learning outcomes as central to the learning process. this learning method allows a student to learn those individual skills they find challenging at their own pace, practising and refining as much as they like. moreover, this approach allows students to build on their strengths not weaknesses.

attributes.label: permanent beta
attributes.description: the term "beta" originally refers to a software version that has not yet been fully developed. when applied to the modern working world, the trend term refers to the increasingly common phenomenon that processes, projects and products and ultimately also the individual occupational biography are in a state of permanent change or adaptation that never reaches a conclusion.

attributes.label: direct trade
attributes.description: direct trade is a further development of fair trade. the main concern of direct trade is to make the supply chain as transparent and short as possible. what makes it special is the direct link between producers and consumers, who usually find each other online. this eliminates cost-intensive middlemen.

attributes.label: we culture
attributes.description: the new power of the "we" can no longer be ignored: Everywhere new forms of communities, collaborations and cooperations are forming - "progressive Wirs", which also open up new alternatives in the face of a divided society.

attributes.label: downaging
attributes.description: while people are in fact getting older and older, they remain subjectively young for longer. older people today are fit and healthy longer than ever before. for most people today, the "perceived age" is 10 to 15 years below the biological age. this downaging determines not only the vital values of older people, but their entire attitude to life and thus their lifestyle, consumption, media use, etc.

attributes.label: virtualization
attributes.description: a virtual campus or e-campus, refers to the online offerings of a college or university where college work is completed either partially or wholly online, often with the assistance of the teacher, professor, or teaching assistant. many colleges and universities now offer such courses (or entire degree programs) either partially or wholly online.

maps.name: GlobalTrends_Beta
maps.description:
**What is the context of a context?**

(version as per january 2020)

Trends reflect models of society that predict overarching themes for years to come, therefore understanding trends and how they can shape the educational business landscape is crucial to the success of an educational organisation.

Trends data were gathered by analyzing and aggregating trend data from various business and research papers into an interactive global trend map. The map includes over 190 trends, grouped according to their main purpose and direction of influence.

Main sources: 
- https://www.zukunftsinstitut.de/
- https://www.trendone.com/
- https://www.britishcouncil.org/
- https://imperialtechforesight.com/

perspectives.name: GlobalTrends_V2
